To those names you can add the New South Wales Bar Association, the Law Society of New South Wales, the Law Council of Australia, the University of Sydney Law School, Flinders University law school, University of New South Wales law school, Adelaide Law School, University of Queensland constitutional lawyers, major firms like Gilbert and Tobin and, of course, the Solicitor-General of Australia. There are many more. It's fair to say that it's a pretty solid line-up giving the Voice the legal and constitutional tick of approval.

I believe that Australians can take comfort from the fact that the proposed changes to the Constitution have been scrutinised by some of the best constitutional minds in the country and they have comprehensively passed muster. So, when the critics attempt to pour scorn on the parliamentary committee and its processes, they do a great disservice not only to themselves but also to those who gave evidence and made submissions. The reality is that it wouldn't matter what the committee did or recommended; these opponents of the Voice wouldn't be happy because they just don't support the Voice. It's one thing not to like or support the Voice; it's another to try to impeach the integrity and undermine the credibility of a parliamentary committee and the committee process itself.

As for the so-called constitutional conservatives or Voice modifiers, I found their evidence and their arguments unconvincing. They want to take away the Voice's ability to talk to the executive, yet in the past those very same people have advocated that it should do just that. I thought a lot of their submissions to the committee veered towards political opinion rather than sound legal principle, and some of it was just plain contradictory. I've been lucky enough to serve as a cabinet minister and I have seen firsthand the significant influence the Public Service can have on proposing, progressing and implementing policy. Of course, the Voice should speak to the executive. It will actually make the executive more accountable on Indigenous issues, which should lead to better outcomes. As Dr Morris pointed out to the committee, had the Voice been in place it may have prevented the destruction of Juukan Gorge.

I've had a look at the proposed amendments that have been suggested and I just don't think they stack up. If you take out clause 2, which is the operative clause, as some are suggesting, the Voice becomes meaningless. If you take out the clause which actually defines the Voice's functions you really will end up with constitutional uncertainty. Watering down the effectiveness of the Voice simply to make it more attractive to a section of a political party ignores sound legal principles and is a flawed endeavour. It's pretty simple: if you're a member of the Liberal Party or National Party and you support the Voice, then stand up and be counted. Wherever you are in this country, now is the time—stand up! If you're a coalition branch member and you support the Voice, stand up. If you're a member of a state or territory parliament, stand up. Be like the member for Bass. Be like the WA Nats. Stand up and be counted. Look at the member for Berowra. The flame of true liberalism hasn't flickered out. So stand up. Stand up and support the Voice.

I think the committee process we have just been through has been very useful in exposing some of the baseless fearmongering and outlandish statements that have accompanied some of the commentary on the Voice. For example, the evidence clearly showed that it's ridiculous to suggest the Voice will have a veto power or will put at risk Anzac Day, federal budgets or nuclear submarine contracts. It won't close beaches, stop recreational fishing or make a separate state of Australia. These claims are arrant nonsense and deeply insulting. Peddling such drivel is deeply irresponsible.

I can remember when the Mabo decision was first handed down. There were also wild claims like farmers would be run off their land, homeowners turfed out of houses and beaches would close. All manner of other doomsday scenarios were touted. And do you know what? The world kept on turning. Australia found a way to make it work. And we will with the Voice.

The Law Council of Australia addressed the question of whether the Voice would create special rights for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples or discriminate based on race. It found that it did not. As former Chief Justice of the High Court Robert French has said, the Voice:
rests upon the historical status of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders as Australia's Indigenous people. It does not rest upon race.
The Voice will not administer programs, it won't have a veto power and it will be subject to the rules for it set by parliament. As Noel Pearson and Shireen Morris have stated:

Let's keep the Voice's ability to advise the Executive in perspective. The Voice's advice is nonbinding. There is no veto. So why shouldn't Indigenous communities have a constitutionally guaranteed role in policy development that impacts their lives? This is the only way to ensure improved practical outcomes flow from the Voice.
And I ask: how could it be that in 2023 our nation's founding document fails to recognise the First Australians? This wrong needs to be made right.
When the Voice committee came to Orange recently, Wellington Wiradjuri man Roy Ah-See said of the Voice:

This is about healing the nation. This is about a better future that's inclusive of all Australians. Our birth certificate doesn't even have Aboriginal people on it … That's an indictment on this country.

But recognition needs to go beyond the tokenistic. Mere symbolic recognition of Australia's First Peoples is not good enough. Recognition needs to mean something. Every year I sit in parliament and listen to the Closing the Gap reports. I could write them all for you, year in, year out. They all say, 'We've made a bit of progress, but the gap isn't closing.' We need to change it up, because what's been happening just isn't good enough for a country like Australia.

When I was in primary school, there was no education about Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander peoples or the cultural heritage they so generously share in so many different ways—none. In recent years, we've come a long way with reconciliation and understanding, and I don't know if reconciliation will be complete in my lifetime. I hope it will, but I don't know. I do know that while ever reconciliation is incomplete, our country will not be complete. The magnificent story of Australia will not be complete.

The referendum is a pivotal moment in our history, and it falls to us—the Australians who are of voting age who will cast their ballots later this year. This is our time and our moment to achieve something momentous, to show the world that we are mature enough to acknowledge what has happened in the past, to acknowledge that the violence and the dispossession has ongoing impacts on the present and move forward together as a united country to make Australia even stronger so that the greatest country on earth can be made even greater.

I urge all Australians, whenever they are, to look into their hearts with the same generosity of spirit shown by Aunty Joyce and Aunty Mary and get behind the Voice. Together, we can truly make history. I commend the bill to the House and the Voice to the people of Australia.

Dr LEIGH (Fenner—Assistant Minister for Competition, Charities and Treasury) (20:43): When this House sits at the beginning of each day we acknowledge the Ngunnawal and Ngambri peoples. The stories of the Ngunnawal are fundamental to this great city. I've been privileged to learn from Tyronne Bell how to speak an acknowledgement of country in Ngunnawal language, and I use it when I'm giving public speeches on Ngunnawal land. I've been privileged too, to walk with Tyronne Bell around the hills of Mount Majura and Mount Ainslie, learning from him about how to understand the local environment. He's shown my kids and my wife Gweneth and I the scar trees and the bush tucker. When I was out running around Mount Majura and Mount Ainslie this morning with my headlamp on, I was thinking about Tyronne and how he helped me better understand the local landscape.

There is much to be ashamed of in the mistreatment of Indigenous Australians, but there's also a great deal to be proud of, in the strength, the resilience, the endurance and the history of Indigenous peoples whose link to the land goes back more than 60,000 years. When the civilisations of ancient Greece and ancient Rome were just getting going, Indigenous Australians had been walking these lands for tens of thousands of years. The book Stories of the Ngunnawal tells the tale of Dorothy Brown Dickson, an Indigenous Ngunnawal person who recounts her experience growing up: 'Even the shopkeepers were prejudiced. You had to wait until the white people were served first in the shops. When Aborigines went to the picture theatre they had to sit down the front by themselves, and the welfare would come up there all the time, checking on people.'

Another extraordinary Ngunnawal elder was Aunty Agnes Shea, who grew up in Yass at a time when discrimination was entrenched in many rural communities. Her first home was in Oak Hill, where there was no electricity or running water and where Agnes had to walk 10 kilometres each way from Oak Hill to the Hollywood Aboriginal reserve school. She recounts how Aboriginal children at the time were limited to certain parts of Yass township and forbidden to speak the Ngunnawal language in public under threat of removal by authorities. Aboriginal children were prohibited from using the school bus service and had to leave school at age 14. When her first baby was born in 1949, Aunty Agnes Shea was one of the first three Aboriginal women allowed to have their babies in Yass Hospital, and a yellow line painted across the corridor marked the boundary of where the Aboriginal women were permitted to walk. In 1949; that's within the lifetime of my own father. Auntie Agnes Shea died earlier this year, at age 91, and her legacy is remembered proudly here in the ACT.

Noel Pearson has noted that many Australians simply do not have Aboriginal people within their circles of family and fellowship with whom they can share fellow feeling. I have to say that one of the ways in which I have appreciated getting to know Indigenous Australians has been through Rob de Castella's Indigenous Marathon Foundation. The Speaker recently hosted an afternoon tea with the 2023 Indigenous Marathon Foundation's squad to hear their extraordinary stories.

Running also reminds me of Pat Farmer, who is currently running 14,000 kilometres around Australia, starting in Hobart and finishing in Uluru, in support of a Voice to Parliament—a former coalition member of this House who wants to put one foot after the other in order to ensure a Voice to Parliament.

I benefited, too, from having the Wreck Bay community—part of the Jervis Bay community—included as part of my electorate of Fenner. When I spoke to elders in that community last week I was proud to announce $44 million of new funding in the budget for housing and new investments in the Booderee National Park. I've learnt so much from those elders, and I thank them for the insights they've shared with me.

Here in the ACT we'll be holding a forum next Monday night with Linda Burney, Peter Yu and Aunty Violet Sheridan to discuss a Voice to Parliament, and I'd encourage those listening to this to tune in online to that forum. The in-person seats were snapped up quickly after we opened registrations, but there are still unlimited opportunities to join us online.

The notion of a voice goes back to the wrong that was done through the principle of terra nullius—the idea that Australia was an empty land, open to British settlers for the taking. The Voice is a response to the wrongs of frontier violence and dispossession. WEH Stanner's 1968 'After the Dreaming' lecture summed it up well:
What may well have begun as a simple forgetting of other possible views turned under habit and over time into something like a cult of forgetfulness practised on a national scale.

Australia has shied too long from the truth. The Constitution is incomplete. Every Australia Day, when we have that discussion about 26 January, it is a reminder of the deeper unease that sits within our country about the relationship between Indigenous and non-Indigenous Australians.

I say to those opposite: don't make a mistake of being on the wrong side of history. I want to remind them of some of the moments in which their predecessors, as conservatives, have been on the wrong side of questions of reconciliation. In 1982, in response to planned peaceful Aboriginal protests for land and civil rights at the Commonwealth Games and proposals for land rights legislation, Premier Joh Bjelke-Petersen and his police minister, Russ Hinze, claimed that 'a secret black army has been in training specifically to provoke violence in Brisbane,' and falsely claimed that 'Aborigines are presently in Libya undergoing guerrilla and terrorist training'. He said that they were aiming to create a 'separate black nation', a part of a 'communist long-range plan to alienate Aboriginal lands from the Australian nation'.

Tim Fischer said in the Mabo debate that 'rightly or wrongly, dispossession of Aboriginal civilisation was always going to happen.' He referred to what he described as the 'guilt industry'. Speaking about the impact of the Mabo judgement, then Victorian Premier, Jeff Kennett, suggested that suburban backyards would be under threat. He said recently that he regretted that comment, saying, 'I think that, like many others I was trying to deal with something that was new, that was undefined.'

Speaking about the proposed Native Title Bill introduced by the Keating government, then opposition leader John Hewson said 'this is a day of shame for Australia that will haunt the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and his government every hour of every day between now and the next election'. John Hewson has since expressed support for the Uluru Statement from the Heart. Indeed, the coalition, under Indigenous affairs minister Nigel Scullion, has professed strong support for the benefits that Native Title can bring to Indigenous Australians, a far cry from the coalition's approach in refusing to negotiate with the Keating government over the native title bill.

It was Prime Minister John Howard who went on the 7:30 Report and held up a picture which showed Australia with 78 per cent of its landmass coloured brown. He said, 'Let me just show you a view of it. This shows 78 per cent of the landmass of Australia covered in brown in this map. Now the Labor Party and the Democrats are effectively saying that the Aboriginal people of Australia should have the potential right of veto over further development of 78 per cent of the landmass of Australia.' That fear mongering was of a piece with John Howard's inability to say 'sorry' to the Stolen Generation, a wrong that awaited Kevin Rudd's election as Prime Minister to set it right.

Amanda Vanstone has said it was probably a mistake to dismantle the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, ATSIC. Tony Abbott has said that it was a mistake of the Howard government to phase out the Community Development Employment Program, the CDEP. The opposition leader, Peter Dutton, walked out of the House of Representatives chamber during the apology to the Stolen Generations and has later acknowledged that he made a mistake.

I say to those opposite: do not be on the wrong side of history. Look to people like the member for Berowra, Ken Wyatt, Mark Textor, Tony Nutt, the member for Bass, and indeed the member for Calare, who gave an extraordinarily powerful speech just now, having moved to the crossbench, and warned against those who would play a spoiling game in trying to stymie a constitutionally enshrined Voice to Parliament.

A constitutionally enshrined Voice to Parliament has support from across sporting codes—the AFL, the NRL, Cricket Australia, Football Australia, Netball Australia, Tennis Australia and the Australian Olympic Committee. It has been extensively debated; indeed, none of the previous 44 referendums have been preceded by more debate, more engagement with parliamentarians, legal experts and community members than this one. There have been extensive reports, an extensive codesign process, First Nations dialogues, and a joint select committee, which made a single recommendation—that the bill be passed without amendment.

To those opposite who say that this is a 'Canberra voice', I offer the words of Auntie Pat Anderson, who says of the Uluru Dialogue delegates, 'What they asked for was a voice to Canberra, not a Canberra voice.' She pointed out that the Uluru dialogue process didn't belong to political parties. They didn't want to be going to Canberra as politicians. They were extraordinary men and women, who, in Pat Anderson's words, have lived their whole lives in their communities helping their own mobs. They want a Voice to Parliament and to Canberra. That simple request, that modest request, represents an outstretched hand of Indigenous Australians.

As Roy Ah-See has noted, 'I think it is critical and essential that this voice has direct communications to the executive—that being, the government and the bureaucrats—because they are the ones that make the decisions.' The Voice should be able to make representations to the executive government.

Australia has changed much in Indigenous affairs over my lifetime. The acknowledgement of country and welcome to country ceremonies were unknown when I was a child and are now a normal part of the way in which life is lived. We look across the ditch to see New Zealand, a country which has Indigenous ceremonies as part of the welcome of foreign leaders, with the dual naming of cities. Canberran Anna Howe argues that maybe Australia could just start with the airports.

We need to move on in that celebratory journey with the same spirit that caused Australian hearts to swell with pride when Cathy Freeman carried the flag at the Sydney 2000 games and went on to win the gold medal in the 400 metres. We look to AFL heroes like Adam Goodes and we look to extraordinarily articulate leaders such as Noel Pearson, who describes a Voice to Parliament as being a matter of building the greatest bridge, bringing together what he describes as the three strands of Australia—our First Peoples, our British institutional inheritance, and our multicultural achievements. As Noel Pearson puts it:

We wait the final stretch. Since we left Uluru on 27 May 2017, millions of Australians have joined the journey. We are excited but anxious. Our hearts are warm and legs wearied, but our eyes are ever searching over those blue mountains for the great emerald city beyond.

A Voice to Parliament will face the truth. It will complete the Constitution. Without our First Nations people in the Constitution, it is a document that fails to capture the totality of Australia today. Just as Pat Farmer will be putting foot after foot on the journey to support a Voice to Parliament, I hope Australians will step up to support the referendum later this year. This can be a powerful, unifying moment for our nation, a nation for which our hearts swell with pride when we take a larger step on the world stage as we continue to advance that journey towards reconciliation that is fundamental to the Australian national project.

Mr BIRRELL (Nicholls—Deputy Nationals Whip) (20:58): I come from Yorta Yorta country near the Goulburn and Murray rivers and they are called the Gaiyila and the Dunghala in Yorta Yorta language. I would never have known any of this as a school boy in Shepparton in the 1980s; that stuff wasn't taught. It is now and that is such a positive thing. Now, Aboriginal culture is not just recognised but it is a source of pride for the whole community. It is continually celebrated. In the south of my electorate is Taungurung country. There is also a proud history and tradition of these people, again, probably also recognised in a way previously neglected.

My electorate was named after Sir Doug Nicholls, a Yorta Yorta man who grew up on the Cumeroogunga Mission near Echuca. He was a sportsman, social worker, pastor, Governor of South Australia and a respected elder in the community. His is an example of service and leadership. He has inspired generations in my electorate to take up that mantel of leadership and service.

Part of the new section in the Constitution would recognise Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples as Australia's first peoples. I think this has been an issue for a long time now. Recognition is long overdue and has broad support. We could move forward with constitutional recognition and it would be a great thing for our nation. Australia didn't begin in 1788. There were peoples and cultures that stretched back for tens of thousands of years, and those are cultures we need to continue to celebrate and honour. It is part of who we are as modern Australia. It is the reason our national anthem was changed. We are not young; part of our culture is ancient. And now, as a confident, modern society, we strive to move forward—one and free.

The issue that many have with this proposal is that it conflates the concept of recognition with a new body called the Voice, a body that would be enshrined in the Constitution permanently, a body that could or would have significant influence on how Australia is governed for all peoples. The issues that affect Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples are issues that affect all Australians because, of course, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples are Australian. There is a dark chapter in our history when they were not respected as citizens. The question is: is this the right mechanism to correct this injustice and does it take us forward or backward? Good people, with pure and principled motivation, of all races, have come to different conclusions on this.

There is a great deal of uncertainty in the community about how this body would operate, what its powers would be and what impact it will have on the current operations of our democracy, and the government of those proposing the Voice have not done much to address the uncertainty of how this will actually work. I strongly believe that if a referendum is put to the people of Australia proposing to alter the Constitution to create a new instrument of government then the people are entitled to know what that instrument is, how it would be formed and what impact it would have in improving the health and prosperity of Indigenous people—as well what impact it would have on the operation of government. Sydney barrister and columnist in The Australian Louise Clegg has suggest that a constitutional convention could have thrashed out all these issues and given comfort to Australians that a fair and exhaustive process would deliver something we could have confidence in.

I also have reservations about a constitutionally enshrined instrument of government based on race. In my maiden speech to parliament, I said that my observation in my community is that we seem to do better when we celebrate each other's different cultural identity and, moreover, embrace each other's humanity—that humanity being a stronger bond between us than any attempts to be amplified by race, gender, sexual orientation or religious view. I believe this is the way we need to move forward as a society. This is not to minimise past injustice or stop promoting legislated positive discrimination where it assists Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples in gaining opportunities in education, careers and economic participation. There are examples of this in my electorate and they are practical examples of Indigenous policy working well, but to cement a new bureaucracy based on race into the Constitution is another level and, in my view, quite a radical step that stands against the principle of equality of citizenship.

While acknowledging that there are Aboriginal people and organisations in my electorate who are supportive of this constitutional amendment, there is a sense in this debate, I believe, of othering. We use terms such as 'they' and 'them', as if Aboriginal people are a unified, homogenous group and therefore all support and demand a separate governance structure in the Constitution. I have this belief that that disrespects the concept of our individualism as people, and a number of Aboriginal Australians have made this point. As an MP representing regional Australia, I also believe in localism. Communities can be vastly different, and the solutions to problems need to reflect the diversity and not be left to a single, national and potentially not properly representative body.

There has been a lot of commentary around the legal implications of the Voice. A range of opinions exist and I acknowledge them all. It must be said that some see no issues for our system of government, but it must also be said that some legal experts do. With a change this significant—that is, a constitutional range—in my view, there's little room for ambiguity. In particular, the addition of the phrase 'advice to executive government' concerns people who hold dear the Constitution and the way our system of government operates.

There has been discussion from a range of legal experts on the likelihood that our system of government will be adversely affected, and I was interested to listen to the member for Menzies in this place some days ago. People's votes may hinge on whether the wording contains unacceptable constitutional risk, and he said:

When we talk of risk it must be assessed with one eye on severity and the other on likelihood, because both matter. It is why we treat risk for aircraft maintenance more seriously than we do for fixing a pushbike. Small risks that might have catastrophic consequences should not be ignored. We should be just as careful when considering a change to our Constitution, our founding and permanent democratic document.
That is why many constitutional amendments must pass such a high bar, higher than that of legislation. It is because of their permanence.

I wish we had had a constitutional convention. I wish we had a process that worked towards a bipartisan position. I wish we didn't have this 'take it or leave it' approach. I wish the debate wasn't framed as 'you're either with us or against us' in relation to a pathway and a mechanism towards reconciliation. Good people from diverse backgrounds and races who want to see reconciliation can and, in fact, do have different views on whether this is the right way to achieve it. It is possible and, in fact, entirely logical to support the aspiration but disagree with the methodology. Put respectfully, those arguments should not attract disparaging comments or attributions of racist overtones. I wish we were voting on constitutional recognition, a referendum that I believe would gain overwhelming support in the community.

I have constituents who are for the Voice in its current form, but I have many others who want reconciliation to occur, who want constitutional reconciliation to occur, who want the gap closed but who believe this is the wrong way to go about it. One said to me, 'I wish I was being presented with something I could vote for, and I believe there are ways to achieve our desired outcomes without significant constitutional change.' I too wish I was being presented with something that, in good conscience, I could support. I think people who know me, maybe, in this place—I haven't been here long—and know me at home also know that I have a heart. Many of the appeals made by proponents of the Voice have appealed to the heart, but a constitutional change of this magnitude requires the head as well as the heart, and we need to examine this really carefully from all angles, and that's a bit hard when we know so little about what it could mean.

I hope all the people in this place understand how much what I'm about to say means. This debate has been very difficult for me. I've had to weigh up many principles. One of those principles is my respect and celebration of First Nations people and culture. Another is the principle of addressing injustice. There are also my personal relationships with some Indigenous leaders in my electorate, which may suffer as a result of my position. I sincerely hope that is not the case, because there is much work we need to do together. Against that, I have a strong belief that Australia has an excellent system of government, one of the greatest in the world. This is based on the Westminster system of representative democracy that we have, which is based on the key principle of equality.

Another key principle, as I stated, is that our shared humanity is more important than amplified divisions. The aspiration is that you are judged by the content of your character and that your ethnic and cultural heritage is something to be celebrated but does not involve the ability to influence government any more than any other Australian. The Constitution should be blind to colour, creed and gender. Our individuality as humans matters and we are not reduced automatically to a member of a group. These principles are important for the future, and for those reasons I personally cannot support this constitutional amendment. I'll vote accordingly in this place. By supporting the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Amendment Bill 2022, which passed earlier this year, setting up the mechanism for referendum, I believe I have not stood in the way of the people of Nicholls having their say.

All Australians deserve the opportunity to discuss this in a respectful way. I really want to emphasise that racism is an insidious evil, and in social media some cowardly practitioners of this have found a canvas. I say to those people: your conduct is un-Australian and unworthy of the good fortune you have as a citizen of this nation. I say to those who believe in the 'yes' case when attempting to characterise those who say no to just consider this quote from President Obama:
"This idea of purity and you're never compromised and you're always politically 'woke' and all that stuff," Mr. Obama said. "You should get over that quickly."
"The world is messy; there are ambiguities … People who you are fighting may love their kids, and share certain things with you."

I wish my constituents well in their deliberations, as I do all Australians, and I implore everyone to debate this really respectfully and come at it aligning with their own values. Good people will come to different conclusions. But it's the Australian people's decision to make, and I will respect their decision.

Ms RISHWORTH (Kingston—Minister for Social Services) (21:10): I am very pleased to rise to support the Constitution Alteration (Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice) 2023. In doing so, I would like to acknowledge that we are meeting on the lands of the Ngunnawal and Ngambri people, and I pay my respect to elders past and present. I also want to touch on the contribution that the Kaurna people make. I'm from the Adelaide Plains, which is where my electorate is. The Kaurna people have a proud connection to the Adelaide Plains. They continue to make a huge contribution to our community and our culture. I particularly want to acknowledge the passing of Aunty Georgina Williams. She has passed away, but her contribution still lives on in my electorate in the southern suburbs of Adelaide.

Our Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples have 65,000-plus years of history and continuous connection with and contribution to this land, and yet their connection to this land is not recognised in our Constitution. This is an anomaly we must fix. This bill provides us with the opportunity to come together to fix this. In this debate, I have heard a number of comments about, 'Why couldn't there be a change of a few words here or there?' The truth of the matter is that there has been a debate for a long time in this country about what a preamble could look like, what words we could put into the Constitution to finally recognise our Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. But the truth is that, when Aboriginal people sat down together at Uluru, they put forward a suggestion of recognition that perhaps hadn't necessarily been canvassed widely before. They put forward their voice about how we could work in partnership together, how we could move forward together.

Today, this bill is about taking up that generous offer of how we can walk together in reconciliation in putting this important question to the people. Despite the fractious debate that has happened, this is not a Canberra voice. This is not a Labor voice. This is not a Labor or Albanese voice, as so many of those commentators opposite have said. This is a suggestion. This is a proposal put forward by First Nations people themselves. If we are truly serious about reconciliation then we have to let go of telling Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people what is best for them. If we really want to work in partnership, we have to listen, we have to be generous and we have to walk together. This bill is about reconciliation. This bill is about listening. This bill is about uniting our country and actually recognising our First Nations people in the constitution.

Taking steps forward to better reconcile with our past, to better recognise Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander history in this country, is always met with resistance. If I think back, one of the first experiences I had after being elected a member of parliament was the national apology, and that had been resisted for many, many years. For many years the national apology had been resisted, but actually having that apology delivered in this parliament was more powerful than I could ever have imagined. The criticism that it was symbolic was just not right, and it has not stood the test of time. In fact, it led to many practical changes, it led to many advances, but it also led to a real reckoning for this country and a real understanding. It was much more than symbolism. I think, looking back now, many people would be thinking, 'Why were we so scared of that apology?'

Think back to native title claims, the Mabo decision and so many other struggles that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people have been through to get recognised and take forward some of their issues and some of their rights. Native title—it's not such a scary thing. There was a big scare campaign put against it; the sky was going to fall down. What we see now is Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people keeping that continuing connection with the land, which is so important, as a result of native title.

This Voice to parliament is the next step in that. It is the next step. And this is not about symbolism. This is actually about listening to the voices of First Nations people because that's good not just for First Nations people; that is good for our country. It is good because we might start to see the outcomes that we need to see when it comes to things like closing the gap. We have continued to fall short of our closing the gap targets. We continue to not achieve some of the critical—critical—things, like reducing the life expectancy gap between First Nations people and other citizens of this country. We do have to look through a lens of not everyone being individual and not everyone having the same opportunities, because that doesn't happen for our Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander brothers and sisters. So we do need to look at new ways of working with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, listening to their voice, working alongside them and in partnership, and the Voice delivers just that.
For those people who are talking about the irreparable damage that this might cause to our Constitution, just listen to the words in this constitutional change:
In recognition of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples as the First Peoples of Australia … there shall be a body, to be called the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice …
That is a simple, generous proposition. It goes on:

… the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice may make representations to the Parliament and the Executive Government of the Commonwealth on matters relating to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples …

I want to speak about this point for a moment because, as a minister that makes decisions on things that particularly affect Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, I don't see this as a hindrance; I see this as a real opportunity. It's an opportunity to gather the voices, concerns and issues, and to be able to listen to those—because at the moment a lot of people claim to speak on behalf of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, but they don't always get it right. So I see this as not something to be scared of, not something to be fearful of, but something that will be really useful and that can be really powerful in helping me and the government of the day make really good decisions in the areas that affect Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.
There are concerns about this Voice that are being put out in the public domain about it somehow affecting the parliament's operations. Part (iii) deals very clearly with that:

The Parliament shall, subject to this Constitution, have power to make laws with respect to matters relating to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice, including its composition, functions, powers and procedures.

There is no veto power here. There is no third chamber. This is a simple proposition, a relatively modest proposition, that was put to us by First Nations people as the way they would like to be recognised in our Constitution, and it is very important that we listen.

Of course, this bill is about putting the question to the Australian people. This bill does offer that choice, and ultimately the Australian people will decide. But I have no doubt in the conversations that I have had that Australians want to see Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people not only recognised but listened to. And, in my conversations with people, there is no doubt that the overwhelming belief is we need to do things better for our Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, but we need to do it with them. We also, of course, importantly, need to listen. So this is an important proposal.

In closing, I have to say, I was given a moment to reflect, because my son came home the other day and told me that in choir they were learning 'From little things big things grow', a very iconic Australian song. We were listening to it together, and there's a little bit of that story where Vincent Lingiari sits down with politicians:
And Vincent sat down with big politicians
This affair they told him is a matter of state
Let us sort it out, your people are hungry
Vincent said no thanks, we know how to wait

Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders have waited long enough. They've waited patiently over time, particularly since the Uluru Statement of the Heart to say: 'We've told you the way forward. We're asking you to come with us.' The time for waiting is over. We will be putting this question to the Australian people, and I have no doubt that we will see a 'yes' vote in the coming referendum because this is the right thing to do to bring our country together.

Mr TEHAN (Wannon) (21:22): Can I thank all members for their contributions to this debate? This is an important debate for our nation and one which has to be conducted in the right tone and in the right manner and everyone needs to be listened to, because I have no doubt that in this parliament that everyone wants to see the best outcomes for Aboriginal people and for Torres Strait Islanders. It is so important that we get those better and improved outcomes, and I think all of us want to see that occur. But just because all of us want to see that occur doesn't mean that we will always agree on what is the best way to do that, and that's why debates like this are incredibly important.

For me, the Voice comes down to a matter of principle. It comes down to a matter of principle from something that I have studied and something that I have lived all my life, and that is the principle of equality before the law. This principle goes back many centuries. As a matter of fact, it goes back to the Ancient Greeks and the great philosopher Aristotle, who, we have to remember, studied the constitutions of the many states that made up Ancient Greece in those times. He said, 'The only stable state is the one in which all men are equal before the law.' I want to repeat that: 'The only stable state is the one in which all men are equal before the law.' Since Aristotle's time, this is something that everybody has strived for, especially in Liberal democracies, to see happen.

Thomas Aquinas referred to Aristotle simply as 'the Philosopher', but he took on board what he said and the ethics and morals of what he taught and made sure that that was practised in the Judaeo-Christian approach. We saw that equality principle go from equality before the law in a constitution to equality before God. That obviously was something that then became central to the Enlightenment project, which led to the flourishing of democracies and liberal democracies across the world, and we saw that equality principle continue on. We saw it most famously spoken of by Martin Luther King, when he said that the United States had to become a country—a democracy—where everyone was equal before the law. What he wanted to see was men judged by their character and not by the colour of their skin.

This equality principle is something that we must continue to strive for in our Constitution today. What we should be seeking to achieve and continuing to search for is to make sure that everyone in this country is treated equally. Sadly, the Voice will not achieve this. The Voice does not help us all strive for that principle of equality before the law.

It's a shame that all of us aren't able to sit down and agree in a bipartisan way about how we could see Indigenous recognition occur in the Constitution. It's a real shame that the Prime Minister has not taken that bipartisan approach. Sadly, on the night that he was elected, the Prime Minister stood up and said, in, I think, the euphoria of the victory, that he was going to implement the Voice, and since the evening that he was elected, he has never once sought bipartisanship. He said, 'This is the proposition and this is what will be enacted.' Now, I think that is a real shame, because if he had said, 'Okay. Let's agree on constitutional recognition,' we would have the whole of this parliament agreed on that principle. Then, what he could have done is say, 'Okay. We also like and want this principle of the Voice,' and he could've broken this into two. So all of us could've agreed on what constitutional recognition would look like, and then we could've debated the Voice. But instead, we have been given one choice, and one choice only, and that is the great shame.

If this referendum goes down, we should be under no illusion as to whose fault it is that it has gone down. It will be the fault of the Prime Minister and the Labor Party and nobody else's, because they could've done this a different way, and they didn't do it a different way. They could've split this choice in two—one about constitutional recognition and one about the Voice—and, in a bipartisan way, we could've agreed on constitutional recognition, and that is a real shame.

Now, I've spoken about equality before the law as a fundamental principle of belief for me and why I cannot support the Voice, but there are other reasons as well—three other reasons in particular. One is that there is no detail, and this is a great shame. I met last week with a young Indigenous leader from Western Victoria, and he is deeply concerned by the Voice. He is deeply concerned because, as a young Indigenous leader, he wants to have a role in the future of his people, yet he doesn't know what that role will look like for him. He doesn't know who the two representatives in Victoria will be. He doesn't know what that will mean in terms of allocation of resources into the regional and rural areas of Victoria. As a matter of fact, he's deeply concerned, as a lot of us are, that the resources end up in the city and they don't end up in regional and rural areas—in particular, in Victoria in this day and age, where regional and rural Victoria is being starved of resources on a daily basis.

It is that lack of detail, I think, that the Australian people have the most concern about. They do not want to be treated like mugs. They want to know what the detail is before they vote, and I call on the government to provide that detail, to get rid of that uncertainty so that people do know what they're voting for. But the sad thing is that, from what we've seen so far, none of that detail is heading our way. Therefore, the Australian people will be asked to vote on this without knowing what they are voting for. The cart will be before the horse. That is not what should be presented to the Australian people. They should know what they are voting for.

This is also a risky proposition, and it's risky because the most eminent legal experts have said it is risky. They have said there are constitutional risks in the language that is being put forward. Even those eminent legal High Court voices who support the Voice have talked about the risk, but they have said, 'Oh, the High Court would never interpret these words in that way, because that would clog up the system of government.' Well, how do we know that? Future appointments to the High Court could actually make decisions that do clog up our system of government. This is a risk that we cannot take when it comes to how government works in this nation.

The bureaucratic quagmire that already prevents decisions being taken at a local, state and federal level is bad enough as it is, without our adding further complications to this. Sadly, that's what potentially could happen under this referendum in its current form. Even though wise counsel has been given to the government to change the very nature of the wording in this referendum question, they have refused to do so, and that is a great shame, because we all have to understand that when you change the Constitution you are changing it permanently. Trying to undo a change to the Constitution is nigh on impossible. So, every time you make a change to the Constitution you have to do so in a purposeful, meaningful and thorough way, with due consideration, because changing the Constitution of this nation is not something that should be done lightly.

In this instance we are adding a new chapter to our Constitution. This is not purely 'some words'; this is adding a new chapter to our Constitution, without the normal processes that would take place. There has not been a constitutional convention, which is a fundamental way in which we do constitutional change. Why wasn't there a constitutional convention? It was because, sadly, once again, the Prime Minister said it was his way or the highway. He wasn't prepared to sit down, have the discussions, do the hard work and have this thoroughly examined. As I've said, if that was the way it was done, I am sure we would have ended up with two questions. And if we had had two questions, at least one of those questions could have got up, and that is the question around constitutional recognition. It is absolutely clear that there would have been clear, bipartisan support for that. Instead, we now have something that has driven division.

I hate to say it, but I think that has been one of the motivations of the Labor Party—to drive that division, especially towards our side of politics. That is not how you should debate, discuss and try to progress things in our Constitution. Our Constitution is far too important for that, and it is a great shame that that bipartisanship has not taken place. In summary, on the basis of that fundamental principle of equality before the law for all, I cannot support the Voice. It is a tradition that goes back as far as Aristotle and is carried right through as a fundamental principle in liberal democracies to this day, and it is something that we must continue to aspire for.

I cannot agree to the Voice for three other fundamental reasons. There's no detail, and no detail will be provided. Providing no detail before you ask people to vote on something as important as this is not treating those people with the respect that they deserve. That lack of detail is concerning for young Indigenous leaders in my local communities, and they deserve better than that. It is risky. Eminent High Court judges have said this. The dissenting report to the joint select committee is well worth reading because it highlights this risk in a very clear manner. It should be read by all before they vote on this. The other reason I cannot agree with this proposition is because this is a permanent change, and it is so difficult to undo something permanent, which ultimately could lead to the wrong outcomes. It is permanent in its nature, and it hasn't been given the due consideration it deserves.

I will conclude on this point. It's the point I started on. All of us in this place want the best outcomes for Indigenous Australians. All of us do. Any thought spoken that says that's not true is abhorrent, because we all agree that we want better outcomes. But what we have to learn to do is to speak, consider and think about the best way to do this, to have proper conversations about it and to make sure that we do deliver those outcomes. If that's what all of us focus on, I am sure that is what we can deliver for Indigenous Australians.

Dr MULINO (Fraser) (21:37): In rising to speak in support of this historic bill, the Constitution Alteration (Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice) 2023, I will start with two brief quotes from the Statement from the Heart:
We seek constitutional reforms to empower our people and take a rightful place in our own country. When we have power over our destiny our children will flourish.
A couple of sentences later, it reads:
We call for the establishment of a First Nations Voice enshrined in the Constitution.
These powerful words capture with such brevity the soul of the issue that we are considering tonight.
As the Prime Minister has said, the Statement from the Heart represents our First Nations people generously offering us their hand. As great Australian writer Miles Franklin wrote in 1954:
Someone to tell it to is one of the fundamental needs of human beings.

This reflects universal yearnings, universal needs and, I believe, universal rights. We all need to be heard to know that we matter. We all need to know that others are listening. Enshrining the Voice in the Constitution is a first step in ensuring that we listen to our First Nations people.

This country has had numerous forms of Indigenous advisory groups, and they have all been slowly disbanded. Without constitutional protection, they were all vulnerable to the whims of the government of the day. The Whitlam government's 1973 National Aboriginal Consultative Committee was removed by the Fraser government in 1977. It was replaced by the National Aboriginal Conference, but that body was stripped of its funding until it was finally discontinued in 1985. The Hawke government instituted the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission in 1990; it was abolished in 2005 by the Howard government. The then Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner, Dr William Jonas, wrote that this decision sought to ensure that the government would only have to deal with Indigenous peoples when it chose to and only on the issues on which it wished to engage. He predicted that abolishing the commission would simply silence Indigenous people at the national level. The trend of silencing voices has continued.

Australian governments pass numerous pieces of legislation that directly affect Indigenous Australia—on land rights, protecting Indigenous culture, the delivery of services and so much more. Indigenous Australians have a right to meaningfully advise governments on matters that affect their lives and the future of their communities. Indigenous people have a fundamental interest in ensuring government hears their views because they bear the brunt of every decision. Non-indigenous Australians have organisations that represent their views to government on all aspects of their lives, including work, business and culture. The proposal to create an Indigenous Voice to Parliament would strengthen the right of Indigenous Australians to be heard and consulted. The views expressed will not be binding on governments. Advice will be provided in much the same way as by many other non-Indigenous organisations.

In addition to respecting the fundamental human need and right to be heard, the proposal to enshrine in the Constitution an Indigenous Voice to Parliament is also about a desire to improve outcomes for Indigenous peoples. Listening to communities leads to better policy and better outcomes. The evidence is there that outcomes are better when we genuinely partner with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities.

One example is Indigenous ranger programs, which support Indigenous people to combine traditional knowledge with conservation training to protect and manage their land, sea and culture. Rangers reported they felt more pride, self-esteem, self-worth, health and wellbeing, with closer connections to family, culture and country. Ranger groups also reported a range of community benefits from these programs, including safer communities, strengthened language and culture, an ability to find meaningful employment, increased respect for women and more role models for younger people.

Then there are the many Aboriginal community controlled health organisations. The evidence shows that low birth weights and infant mortality rates in the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community have declined significantly over the period of increased investment in primary health care delivered through the ACCHS sector.

We went to the 2022 election with a clear commitment to hold a referendum on the Voice in this term of parliament. The Australian people elected a government that was committed to holding this referendum. The proposal for a referendum to enshrine the Voice to Parliament is not just a gesture of reconciliation, as important as that is. It is also a key protection against a return to a future when the voices of our First Nations people are ignored and silenced.

Some say, 'Why now?' The promise of constitutional reform has been a multidecade process. The Uluru Statement From The Heart, itself the culmination of one of our nation's greatest consultation processes, was shared with this nation six years ago. That remarkable statement, which will go down in the annals of our nation's history, deserves to be acted upon now. The passage of this bill and the referendum that will follow it are an opportunity for our nation to accept the generous offer of our First Nations people and, in so doing, take a long overdue step to a better future. It's time.

Ms SHARKIE (Mayo) (21:43): I rise to speak in support of the Constitution Alteration (Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice) 2023 so that all Australians will have the opportunity to vote on the proposed voice for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in the Constitution. The bill will, if passed, seek to ask Australian citizens to insert into the Constitution a new chapter 9 on recognition of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples which will, if approved at the referendum, contain a new section 129. Subsection (i) of the new section 129 will provide for the establishment of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice in the Constitution, independent from government. Subsection (ii) will set up the function of the Voice as making representations to parliament and the executive government about matters relating to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. Subsection (iii) will provide parliament with the powers it needs to make the laws about matters relating to the Voice, including its composition, functions, powers and procedures. I respect that this form of the bill was considered best by those who drafted the bill.

Many in this place have been very vocal about their reasons for wanting either a 'yes' or a 'no' vote. But I think we've been hearing enough from politicians. This is about a referendum and a vote by and for the people, not just politicians. Everyone of us in here has the same one vote, as does somebody who's waiting at the bus stop or somebody who's just in their home, probably watching television at the moment and probably not listening to the parliament!

I've chatted with some of the local Aboriginal elders in Mayo. I've heard from constituents who will be voting yes and constituents who will be voting no, and the people who have those views are both Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal. I've heard from many constituents who have questions or are uncertain about what the Voice will mean. I've heard from many constituents who were hopeful that there would perhaps be two sections of amendments—first, a question that would seek to provide recognition in the preamble of the Constitution, and then the further question, as proposed, on the actual Voice. And I have heard from many who don't understand what the Voice will mean in practice and many who, when you ask them about the Voice, respond blankly and say, 'What voice?' This does concern me. I do understand that many people are busy with their own lives and tune out of politics between elections. But we must also remember that anyone under 45 hasn't actually participated in a referendum before, so we need to make sure that that civic education is done.

That is what I see as the most important role for members of parliament—not campaigning and telling people how we think they should vote but sharing the information to help address any questions or gaps in knowledge and understanding, and the actual process of what a referendum does and means. I must say I don't feel that I have all the answers. People ask me, 'Does it mean the Voice will be limited to certain pieces of legislation, such as native title, or does it mean that the Voice will be consulted on every piece of legislation, such as social services or health legislation?' I don't know all of the answers. I'm hoping that I will be able to have more information as we head towards the referendum, so that I can share that information with my community.

I recognise that Australians are historically conservative when it comes to constitutional change, and that double majorities are a higher threshold—both a majority in the popular vote and a majority of the states. We haven't seen a successful referendum in our nation in over 45 years, not since the 1977 referendum which, among other changes, amended the Constitution to allow territory electors to vote in referenda. Because of this, I am concerned about what it could mean for Australia, and the pain that could be caused to some Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people if the referendum doesn't pass. This is a conversation that our community needs to have openly to clarify concerns and to ensure everyone understands what they are voting for or against.

Of course, to support the exercise of every Australian voter's right to participate in this referendum, I will be supporting this bill. To ensure that those voting in this referendum are well informed, I encourage the government to ensure that the official pamphlets setting out clear and concise information regarding both the 'yes' and 'no' cases are prepared and published as soon as possible. I hope that every Australian will then have the information they need to carefully consider their vote in this referendum. I commend the bill to the House.

Ms FERNANDO (Holt) (21:49): I acknowledge and pay my respect to the Ngunnawal and Ngambri peoples on whose land we gather. I extend this acknowledgement and respect to the Boonwurrung people on whose land my electorate of Holt is located. It is a great honour to rise to support the passage of the Constitution Alteration (Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice) 2023.

Australia is fortunate to have had the oldest living culture as the custodians of its land, waters and sky for over 60,000 years. Their relationship to the land that we now call home pre-dates calling this land Australia and extends beyond the practice of writing itself. The lack of mention of our First Nations peoples in our Constitution means that our nation's principal document is without its heart. The constitutional amendment in this bill will rectify more than 120 years of significant and grave oversight that we no longer can ignore.

Denying their place in our Constitution is denying their rightful place in our national identity and history. The passage of this alteration to our Constitution through the parliamentary process and the referendum later this year is an endeavour to put the heart in the soul of our country. This dispossession of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander languages and cultures and top-down policymaking for Indigenous issues have inflicted deep and continuing wounds on generations of First Nations people. Many suffer intergenerational trauma as a result of this history, and it continues to be a blot on the fabric of this nation.

This is not to say that we have not attempted to make things better. In 1967 over 90 per cent of Australians voted to include Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in certain population counts and allow the Commonwealth to make special laws about them. In 1992 the Mabo decision overturned the legal fiction that Australia was terra nullius—that is, territory belonging to none—and legally recognised the relationship of First Nations peoples to our country. In 2008 Prime Minister Kevin Rudd apologised to the Stolen Generation, and that has been followed by successive national agreements on Closing the Gap.

Yet, despite genuine intentions to atone for past sins, governments' efforts to date have not sufficed. First Nations people have faced considerable hurdles unique to them, and 11 of 15 Closing the Gap targets are not on track. On the current trajectory, the gap will not be closed by 2030. In fact, on the current trajectory it will not be closed in our lifetimes. Our current approach is failing, and it is time for a different approach. It is time to listen to the overwhelming majority of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander delegates who gathered from around the country and endorsed the Uluru Statement from the Heart. The resounding message of the Uluru statement was simple: Voice, Treaty and Truth. This bill corresponds to a call for a First Nations Voice to be enshrined in the Constitution. On the other hand, the efforts towards a makarrata commission for treaty making an truth-telling is underway and will continue beyond the referendum. A Voice to Parliament is a modest yet crucial reform. It complements the existing structures of Australia's democratic systems and enhances the normal functioning of government and the law by giving us an opportunity to collaborate and partner with First Nations people in ensuring a better future for them.

The fearmongering by those opposite is hollow, and I would like to draw their attention to a cartoon by renowned illustrator Cathy Wilcox in the Voice to Parliament Handbook, by Thomas Mayo and Kerry O'Brien. In the cartoon an adult addresses two of their children by saying, 'No Billy, by giving Maisy a Voice, it won't take away yours.' It's that simple.

Every day is an opportunity to rectify past injustices so that they do not continue in the future. Those elected to this chamber and the other place have a choice between making history and repeating it. Choose wisely. I thank the House.

Mr REPACHOLI (Hunter) (21:54): I rise to contribute to the debate on the Constitution Alteration (Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice) 2023. I'd like to start off by saying 'yes'. I say yes to recognition of our First Nations people in our nation's most important document, the Constitution. I say yes to an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice to our parliament. I say yes to better outcomes for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples.

I came to this place because I truly believe in equal opportunities for all and I wanted to help to create a better future for all Australians. We cannot achieve equal opportunity or a better future for all when we continue to see Indigenous communities disadvantaged and left behind. It is a sad truth that Indigenous people in this country face a lot of issues that non-Indigenous people do not have to face. Too often, Indigenous people are overrepresented in a range of these areas. This is seen when it comes to issues in areas like health, education and housing. When a particular group in our society is doing it tough, it's common sense that our parliament addresses it. It's a simple fact that listening to the community leads to better laws and better policies and better outcomes. A simple act of listening will make a practical difference on the ground. We know this because we have seen it work before. We have seen better outcomes when partnering with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities.

We cannot continue to sit here in our fancy offices, far away from the communities who need us to create change, pretending we know best for these people when it clearly we do not. The definition of insanity is doing the same thing over and over again and expecting a different outcome, and I think that's what we've had in the past 100-plus years of this parliament. Listening to the people from these communities about the issues that affect them just makes sense. We have to face the facts. While we have come a long way in this country, we have ultimately failed in creating a country which is as equal for First Nations people as it is for non-First Nations people. While there have been advisory bodies in place in the past, none of them have stood long enough for them to make a true and lasting impact. That's why we need to implement the Voice properly and make sure it's enshrined in our Constitution. This is the best chance we've have to address the injustice of the past and create change that will deliver a better future.

The Australian people hear lots of doubts being raised by some people in this place, but the Solicitor-General of this country, who I think might know a little bit more about what the impact of the Voice may be than those who are opposing it, states:
The proposed amendment is not only compatible with the system of representative and responsible government established under the constitution, but it enhances that system.
Listening to what is spouted by those opposite over the opinion of the Solicitor-General is the equivalent of having a footy player telling a cricket player how to hold a bat.

The Voice will be a permanent, independent advisory body which will make representations to the Australian parliament and the executive government on laws and policies that affect Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples. One of the core functions will be to make representation to the executive government. This is nothing threatening. I do it dozens of time a day on behalf of my own constituents. It's a fundamental part of a representative democracy. The Voice will be able to make these representations proactively. The Voice would will be able to respond to requests for representation from parliament and the executive government. The parliament and executive government should also seek representations in writing from the Voice early in the development and proposal of laws and policies. The Voice will be chosen by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples based on the wishes of the local communities—this is vital in making sure that this is not only a voice which is heard but also a voice that is effective. Those chosen as members will serve on the Voice for a fixed period. This ensures regular accountability to their communities. In order for this Voice to be truly representative, members will be chosen from each state and territory and the Torres Strait Islands. The Voice will have specific remote representatives as well as representation from the mainland Torres Strait Islander population. The Voice will have a balanced gender representation—

The SPEAKER: Order! Debate has adjourned, and resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting. The member will have leave to continue speaking when the debate is resumed.
NOTICES
Presentation
The following notices were given:
Mr Burke to present a Bill for an Act to establish Creative Australia, and for related purposes. (Creative Australia Bill 2023)

Mr Burke to present a Bill for an Act to deal with consequential and transitional matters arising from the enactment of the Creative Australia Act 2023, and for related purposes. (Creative Australia (Consequential and Transitional Provisions) Bill 2023)

Ms Rishwor th to present a Bill for an Act to amend the law relating to social security, family assistance and veterans' entitlements, and for related purposes. (Social Services and Other Legislation Amendment (Strengthening the Safety Net) Bill 2023)
Mr O'Connor to present a Bill for an Act to amend the Trade Support Loans Act 2014, and for related purposes. (Trade Support Loans Amendment Bill 2023)

Mr Keogh to present a Bill for an Act to amend the law relating to veterans' affairs and military rehabilitation and compensation, and for related purposes. (Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (Miscellaneous Measures No. 2) Bill 2023)
Dr Aly to present a Bill for an Act to amend the law relating to family assistance, and for related purposes. (Family Assistance Legislation Amendment (Child Care Subsidy) Bill 2023)
Ms Fernando to move:
That this House:
(1) acknowledges the popularity of the Government's Fee-Free TAFE policy, demonstrated by the almost 150,000 enrolments in the first quarter of 2023;
(2) recognises that fee-free TAFE is:
(a) driving enrolments in sectors with recognised skills shortages and securing a domestic workforce to deliver on current and future priorities;

(b) providing training opportunities to priority groups including First Nations Australians, young people (between the ages of 17 to 24), people out of work or receiving income support, unpaid carers, certain categories of visa holders, women undertaking study in non-traditional fields, people with disabilities and people from culturally and linguistically diverse communities;
(c) enabling greater opportunities for Australians to gain skills for rewarding employment and to obtain secure, well-paid jobs;
(d) investing in our greatest resource, our people, and ensuring that no Australians are held back or left behind as the Australian economy transitions; and
(e) providing important cost-of-living relief to Australian students;
(3) commends the Commonwealth and state and territory governments for jointly establishing a $1 billion 12-month National Skills Agreement in 2023, delivering 180,000 places this year; and
(4) welcomes budgeting for a further 300,000 places to be made fee-free from 2024, supporting TAFE's central role in the Vocational Education and Training sector.

The DEPUTY SPEAKER (Ms Claydon )
took the chair at 09:30.

The DEPUTY SPEAKER (Ms Claydon )
took the chair at 09:30.
CONSTITUENCY STATEMENTS
Environment

Mr WILKIE (Clark) (09:30): Tasmanians are naturally proud of our natural environment, so imagine our community's alarm and sometimes even anger at the increasing likelihood of losing so much that we love. Currently, more than 650 different plant and animal species are listed as threatened in Tasmania, including six critically endangered vertebrae—for example, the Maugean skate, an ancient fish found only in the waters of Macquarie Harbour. Its population almost halved between 2014 and 2021, while the state government was cheering on the seemingly unrestrained salmon-farming in the harbour, despite it so obviously causing oxygen depletion and creating dead zones. Don't get me wrong, the salmon industry is an important contributor to the state, but it has a responsibility to do the right thing by local communities and the environment, just as the government has the responsibility to hold the industry to account, and neither is the case right now.

The Swift parrot is another species facing extinction within the next decade without urgent action. Here, again, governments are failing us by allowing grossly irresponsible destruction of habitat. The thing is, it wouldn't be hard to turn this around, because by one assessment only seven per cent of public forests currently available for logging need to be protected in order to give the Swift parrot a fighting chance. But even this has been too much for both state and federal governments, who have instead exempted the Regional Forest Agreements from the EPBC Act and related national environmental standards. Moreover, our natural heritage is under threat from sweet deals between developers and governments. For instance, the luxury helitourism project proposed for Lake Malbena would pay just $4,000 per year to lease public land and exploit a wilderness heritage area for the benefit of wealthy tourists. This is markedly less than what a load of families in Hobart are paying in rent every couple of months right now.

Tasmanians well know what it's like to be on the environmental front-line. For example, the flooding of Lake Pedder was a catastrophe which destroyed a place of incomparable beauty and birthed the environmental movement in this country. The campaign to save the Franklin River prompted Australia more widely to recognise the value of our national heritage and the voices of campaigners. Thank heavens that the Hawke federal government intervened to save the Franklin—so too should we be pleased with this federal government's Nature Positive Plan, which sets out a goal of improving Australia's environmental laws to stop and reverse biodiversity loss. But such steps are still only the start, and Australians—Tasmanians in particular—want more, much more. We want genuinely deep reform of environmental laws which would reflect the value of our natural heritage, protect species, and genuinely establish for Australia a global reputation as a clean, green nation.
E-Cigarettes and Vaping Products

Ms COKER (Corangamite) (09:32): In February last year I spoke in this place about Steven, a distressed father of two young boys, who inhaled from a friend's grape-flavoured vape in a primary school bathroom. Only a week later, Steven's five-year-old was frantically rushed to hospital, struggling to breathe. Steven's son now has an ongoing asthmatic condition. Stories like this are not uncommon. Parents and teachers are increasingly concerned about vaping and its role as a precursor to smoking and nicotine addiction. We know that over the past 12 months Victoria's poisons hotline has taken 50 calls about children under four becoming sick from ingesting or using a vape, and this is just the tip of the iceberg.

I acknowledge Steven and all the brave parents who have spoken out and advocated for legislation to better regulate vaping. As a result, I can proudly stand here today and declare that the Albanese government are listening and we are acting. Earlier this month, our health minister announced that the Commonwealth will contribute more than $730 million towards stamping out vaping and cigarettes. When the minister made this announcement, Steven dropped into my office with his boys to celebrate.

span.span: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

p.span: Ms COKER: When the minister made this announcement, Steven dropped by my office with his boys to celebrate. Steven said at the time:
I'm grateful for the efforts our current government is making. Everyone in our community should see and welcome the need for this change and the safe regulation of vapes …
To realise there was so little known about vaping, and the poisonous chemicals they contain, is frightening.
I love my children dearly, and to see this harm come to them never really leaves one's mind.
For Steven, and for all parents, this reform is long overdue.

Our plan begins with the banning of single-use, disposable vapes, a public health information campaign on the dangers of vaping and funding for quit support programs. It will also include: an increase to the minimum quality standards for vapes by restricting flavours, colours and other ingredients; requirements for pharmaceutical-like packaging; reduction in the allowance of nicotine concentrations; and an increase in the tax on tobacco by five per cent per year for three years.

No longer will we stand by as children as young as four inhale from these devices which can contain more than 200 toxic chemicals, causing cancer and other chronic lung conditions. Some of those chemicals are found in nail polish remover and weed killer. This is unacceptable. No longer will we stand by and allow vaping to create another generation of nicotine addicts.
Health Care: Pharmacists

Mr LEESER (Berowra) (09:48): As the grandson of a pharmacist, I know pharmacies are an essential service communities rely on. Pharmacists are the front line of health care in our communities. They are professionals, community leaders and counsellors and they operate a triage service, helping people understand and manage their health needs. I see it all the time. Our community pharmacies keep many people afloat.

I have great pharmacists in my community, like Alex Torrens from Hornsby Heights Pharmacy, Adam Shanahan from Pennant Hills Pharmacy, Warwick Best of Best's Pharmacy Cherrybrook, Yvonne Nguyen from Carmen Drive Community Pharmacy, Sunny To from the Priceline pharmacy at Beecroft, Susan Cole from Mt Colah Pharmacy, Diksha Mehrotra from Friendly Pharmacy at Round Corner, Susan Low and Leanne Plumbridge from Mount Colah Pharmacy and many, many others.

Given all this, when I hear from pharmacists in my community that are deeply worried about a policy change, I pay attention. In recent weeks, I've had phone calls, emails and visits from pharmacists across the Berowra electorate. They are all telling me the same thing. They are saying the government's 60-day dispensing policy could be fatal for community pharmacies and bad for patients. It will make the most unwell people in our communities even more vulnerable. We risk seeing the closure of pharmacies in communities that need them most.

Sixty-day dispensing makes sense on paper. Cheaper medicines and more efficiency—who would oppose that? The government's policy falls into the notorious trap of not enough listening to the people who will be actually affected. As the Council of Small Businesses of Australia said, 'Initially, the proposal seems to expect small business pharmacies to fund consumer cost-of-living savings.' Dr Nick Coatsworth said:
